title: Year-End Financial Checklist: 10 Things to Do Before January
excerpt: December is the perfect time to review your finances and set up next year for success. Use this checklist to end the year strong.
content:
## Why Year-End Financial Review Matters

December is not just holiday season. It is the ideal time to:

- Capture tax benefits before they expire
- Review what worked and what did not
- Set up systems for next year
- Start January ahead instead of behind

This checklist covers everything to address before the ball drops.

## The 10-Item Year-End Checklist

### 1. Max Out Tax-Advantaged Accounts (If Possible)

**Deadlines:**
- 401(k): Contributions must be made by December 31 through payroll
- HSA: Can contribute until April 15 for prior year
- IRA: Can contribute until April 15 for prior year

**Actions:**
- Check how much you have contributed to 401(k)
- If not maxed, see if you can increase final paychecks
- HSA and IRA can wait but consider contributing now

**2024 limits:**
- 401(k): $23,000 ($30,500 if over 50)
- IRA: $7,000 ($8,000 if over 50)
- HSA: $4,150 individual, $8,300 family

### 2. Review Health Insurance for Next Year

**Open enrollment typically ends mid-December.**

**Review:**
- Did your health needs change?
- Are your doctors still in-network?
- Is there a better plan option?
- Should you change HSA/FSA contributions?

**FSA reminder:** Use-it-or-lose-it accounts may forfeit unused funds. Spend remaining FSA money on eligible expenses.

### 3. Harvest Tax Losses (If You Invest)

Tax-loss harvesting: Selling investments at a loss to offset gains.

**How it works:**
- Sell investments that have dropped in value
- Use losses to offset capital gains
- Can offset up to $3,000 of ordinary income if no gains

**Caution:** Avoid wash sale rule (buying substantially identical security within 30 days).

### 4. Make Charitable Donations

Donations must be made by December 31 for this year's tax deduction.

**If you itemize deductions:**
- Donate appreciated stock (avoid capital gains)
- Bunch donations in one year if near standard deduction threshold
- Keep receipts for all donations

**Even if you do not itemize:** Donations still do good, even without tax benefit.

### 5. Review Your Budget Performance

Look back at the year:

- How did actual spending compare to budget?
- Which categories were consistently over or under?
- What unexpected expenses occurred?
- Did you meet savings goals?

**Use [Pennywise](https://apps.apple.com/si/app/pennywise-finance-tracker/id6754343519) to pull your annual spending summary.**

**What to do with insights:**
- Adjust next year's budget based on reality
- Create sinking funds for surprise categories
- Celebrate what went well

### 6. Check Your Credit Report

Free annual credit reports from all three bureaus at annualcreditreport.com.

**Review for:**
- Accounts you do not recognize
- Errors in personal information
- Late payments incorrectly reported
- Overall credit health

**Why it matters:** Errors can affect loan rates and applications. Catch them early.

### 7. Update Beneficiaries

Life changes may mean beneficiary designations are outdated.

**Check beneficiaries on:**
- 401(k) and IRA accounts
- Life insurance policies
- Bank accounts (POD/TOD)
- Any accounts with beneficiary designations

**Common issues:**
- Ex-spouse still listed
- Deceased person still listed
- Children born after accounts opened

### 8. Organize Tax Documents

Start gathering documents now for easier tax filing:

**Income documents:**
- W-2s (arrive in January)
- 1099s (investment income, freelance income)
- Year-end pay stubs

**Deduction documents:**
- Charitable donation receipts
- Medical expense records
- Property tax records
- Mortgage interest statements

**Create a tax folder** (physical or digital) and add documents as they arrive.

### 9. Calculate Your Net Worth

Net worth = Assets - Liabilities

**Assets:**
- Bank account balances
- Investment account values
- Retirement account values
- Home equity (if owned)
- Other valuable assets

**Liabilities:**
- Credit card balances
- Student loans
- Car loans
- Mortgage balance
- Other debts

**Track year over year:** Seeing net worth grow (or debt shrink) is motivating.

### 10. Set Financial Goals for Next Year

Use year-end reflection to set next year's goals:

**Good goals are specific:**
- Save $6,000 to emergency fund
- Pay off $4,000 credit card balance
- Increase 401(k) contribution to 15%
- Track all expenses for the full year

**Write them down. Schedule monthly reviews.**

## Quick Reference Deadlines

| Task | Deadline |
|------|----------|
| 401(k) contributions | December 31 |
| FSA spending | December 31 (or grace period) |
| Charitable donations | December 31 |
| Tax-loss harvesting | December 31 |
| Open enrollment | Usually mid-December |
| IRA/HSA contributions | April 15 (for prior year) |

## Week-by-Week December Plan

### Week 1 (Dec 1-7)

- [ ] Review health insurance options
- [ ] Check 401(k) contribution status
- [ ] Start organizing tax documents

### Week 2 (Dec 8-14)

- [ ] Complete open enrollment decisions
- [ ] Review investment accounts for tax-loss harvesting
- [ ] Make charitable donations

### Week 3 (Dec 15-21)

- [ ] Spend remaining FSA funds
- [ ] Update beneficiaries if needed
- [ ] Pull annual credit reports

### Week 4 (Dec 22-31)

- [ ] Review annual budget performance
- [ ] Calculate year-end net worth
- [ ] Set goals for next year
- [ ] Ensure any final contributions are made

## Starting Next Year Right

Complete this checklist, and January 1 becomes:

- Tax documents organized
- Goals clearly set
- Systems ready to go
- Insights from last year applied

No scrambling. No forgotten deadlines. Just forward momentum.

## The 15-Minute Version

If you only have 15 minutes, do these:

1. Check if you can increase 401(k) for final paychecks
2. Spend remaining FSA money
3. Make any planned charitable donations
4. Set one specific financial goal for next year

Better than nothing. Come back for the rest when you can.
